獻給有上進心的台灣學生， 2:43 ~ 3:16 我認為意思是：依據國中時對指數的理解容易將 e^x 視為 e 連成 x 次，但這個想法是有問題的，這不是 e^x 的定義；因為依照影片解釋至此，e^x 應視為「將加法變成乘法的手段 (函數)」，此處的加法器本身不限定只能做 1+1 而是可以直接作 n+m (令 n, m 是任意數)；除非你所作的加法是 1+1+1+1+...(連加 x 次) 這種特殊情況，那才可以把 e^x 解釋為 (e^1) 連乘了 x 次

There is one other continuous function that satisfies f(x+y)=f(x)f(y) for all complex x and y. It is the identically zero function f(x) = 0. This function is equal to g(x) = 0^x only if we restrict the domain to positive real numbers; elsewhere, g is undefined. Assuming the axiom of choice, there are also uncountably many discontinuous functions satisfying that functional equation, but none of them can be constructed. (A proof of the last statement relies on the existence of a Hamel basis of R treated as a vector space over Q, which relies on the axiom of choice.)

What are ADDERS AND MULTIPLIERS?

Just think on this, you have the WHOLE numeral line, then you add any number to every number on this line (...,-2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3,...)
We'll add 3
This 3 will be added to every number in this line and their value will change (-1 +3, 0 +3, 1 +3, 2 +3,...)
So now, the position of every number in the line is not the one it must be (we added 3 to 0, so now it will be 3) hence, we have to "move" the line sideways for make things normal (THIS IS LINEAL CHANGE OF POSITION, here the number "3" is the adder)

The same thing occurs if we multiply every single number of the line, excepting that 0 will still in the same spot ( 0 × n = 0), but every number will change exponentially, so that this line have to "stretch" or "retract" in order of "keeping things normal"

Again, all of these is a LINEAL change, in a 1 dimension plane

Now Imagine a 2 dimensional change of position

Okay people, for those who didn't understand, YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT MATRIXES AND VECTORS MULTIPLYING WITH EACH OTHER, their product generate a change of position in the x,y plane (2 dimension plane)

for those wondering how they figured this out: the infinite series of sin=x/1!-x^3/3!+x^5/5!-x^7/7!.... and cos=x^0/0!-x^2/2!+x^4/4!-x^6/6!+x^8/8!... to relate this to e consider the infinite series of e^(ix), it goes=1+ix-x^2/2!-ix^3/3!+x^4/4!+x^5/5!-x^6/6!-ix^7/7!+x^8/8!... now if we seperate the series into rational and irrational we get (1-x^2/2!+x^4/4!-x^6/6!+x^8/8!)+i(x-x^3/3!+x^5/5!-x^7/7!) or better know as cox+isinx=e^(ix), a special case arrises when pi is plugged in for x sin(pi)=0 and cos(pi)=-1 therefore e^(ipi)=-1 or e^(ipi)+1=0, eulers formula

That is, if we simply ask what "equals" means, we can see this sort of mode mixing is simply true to the extent that it is solvable but ultimately meaningless. It is sort of the mathematical equivalent of what Dan Dennett calls a "deepity." In a way the equal sign is the problem. When we say something is equal to negative one, are we really saying "results in" or "ends on" instead? In that case all of this is a fancy way of counting Cardinals in a stupidly complicated way only to end up at negative one. It lacks any utility or meaning; meerly the mental masturbation of masochistic mathematicians.

Firstly. Pi is defined as C/d. The use of d/2 = r just makes for unnecessary confusions.

Secondarily, 'i' is in effect polar instead of cartesian, as you properly show, constrained to the limits +-1 in both magnitude and rotation.

These two things, in turn, lead to further confusions.

Also worth noting is that -(1) is a vector. The number is in the magnitude of that vector, as shown. It is NOT the whole thing together which has been a confusion in Mathematics since who knows when.

A further confusion is that 0 and 0.0 represent 'the origin'. A dual use of the symbols that also has persisted almost forever.

The original term was ⊙ which decimalisation then replaced with 0 and 0.0. This then leads to all the undefined's that have plagued Maths and Science since then.

I would love to see your explanations with those, quite minor, details cleared up.

I think I came up with a more intuitive proof than the one you gave here (think it was before this video was made as well). It's based on defining a general notion of what iterating to imaginary powers means (so you don't have to just accept that e^x is a mapper between two specialized sorts of number and instead just continue with the intuitive definition of exponentiation as iterated multiplication), idea requires just a basic understanding of principles of calculus (though the complete proof requires knowing e^x is it's own derivative to proof it's the particular base that works for the equation), and the rest of it is just geometry. The basic is idea is that any iterated function traces out as orbital as you raise it to a real power, and changing the function being iterated changes these orbits. The change raising to real power does is just to amplify the derivative of the orbital, and raising to a complex power is essentially the same, it just requires rotating the derivative of the orbital field as well. The key thing iterated multiplication makes rays as orbitals, so imaginary iterated orbitals forms concentric circles. The base of exponentiation is one, so that means the path of imaginary exponentiation will be from one along the circle around the origin passing through one. There is pi length path to get from 1 to -1 along that path, and when the base is e and the distance stays at one from the origin no other factors have to be multiplied in as the magnitude of the derivative stays at one, and that completes the proof.

Twelve Steps From The Cube, To The Sphere

Calculating the surface area and volume of a 6 centimeter diameter sphere, obtained from a 6 centimeter cube.

1. Measure the (a) cubes height to obtain its Diameter Line, which in this case is 6 centimeter’.

2. Multiply 6 cm x 6 cm to obtain the square area of one face of the cube; and also add them together to obtain the length of perimeter to the square face = Length 24 cm, Square area 36 sq cm.

3. Multiply the square area, by the length of diameter line to obtain the cubic capacity = 216 cubic cm.

4. Divide the cubic capacity by 4, to obtain one quarter of the cubic capacity of the cube = 54 cubic cm.

5. Multiply the one quarter cubic capacity by 3. to obtain the cubic capacity of the Cylinder = 162 cubic cm.

7. Divide the cubes surface area by 4, to obtain one quarter of the cubes surface area = 54 square cm.

CYLINDER TO SPHERE

12. Multiply the one quarter surface area by 3 to obtain the three quarter surface area of the Sphere = 121 & a half square cm, to the surface area of the Sphere

Absolutely fantastic video, but it leaves one question (which was indirectly answered in the second video btw, but required some backtracking).

You say the multiple functions satisfy the property f(x+y) = f(x)f(y), and then claim that one stands out as being the most natural: e^x (also hidden puns are the best puns). The question I had initially watching this video is... why? This is only muddled by the fact that the "defining" property of e, e^(x+y)=(e^x)(e^y) (and implying that there is something special about e), is in fact just a defining property of any exponential. You later clear this up somewhat by mentioning that all other exponentials satisfy this, but as a result it is hard to see why e is in any way special in regards to this definition.

For those wondering, the reason why e is special is answered in his second video, and has to do with e^x being its own derivative: "When we zoom in on e^x taking the point associated with a particular adder, to the point associated with some multiplier, it resembles that very multiplier as it does so." The importance of this point is further examined in the comment section:

"""""""
Baumgarten Ralph:
then all of the exponential functions 2^x, 3^x, i^x etc can be derived by the defining property of f(x+y)=f(x)f(y); and does that mean 2^iπ,3^iπ,i^iπ,... all equals respectively to -1? cause those functions will also convert adder to multiplier..then why e-specially e?

3Blue1Brown:
Good question, I did not emphasize this point well enough. All those other exponentials still draw circles when you raise them to an imaginary power, it's just that they do so at different rates. This means iπ might not get mapped exactly halfway around the circle, but would instead map to some other point on the circle.

The main point I wanted to make in the previous video was that the property f(x+y)=f(x)f(y) can give an intuitive feel for why raising something to an imaginary power would draw circles at all. In this video, I wanted to show why of all the functions that satisfy this property, the reason e^x draws the circle so naturally (meaning at a unit rate) is because it is its own derivative (whereas the other functions like 2^x, 3^x, etc. are all merely proportional to their own derivative)."
"""""""
tl;dr: e is special because it draws the circle at the unit rate (e^(iπ) = cos(π) = -1, ie π up the complex plane is only one half turn with base e).

Actually, if you are looking for a deep mathematical reason for a relationship to hold, you might want to try to generalize it.

Indeed, there is an analogous formula which holds in Lie algebras: the special property of e is that exp(x) is an eigenfunction of the derivative, and the mapping exp(ad), where ad is the adjoint representation of a Lie algebra, is equal to the adjoint action Ad of the associated Lie group. That ad is a "derivation" (algebraic generalization for derivative) follows from the Jacobi identity. So the number e is incredibly important in algebra and differential equations.

The unit circle is a Lie group whose tangent space at 1 is the imaginary line in the complex plane. Euler's formula immediately follows since the cosine and sine functions smoothly parametrize the unit circle. In broader applications, Euler's formula will take more general forms. For example, in matrix Lie groups, you can take the exponential of an entire matrix: if A is an involutory matrix (the square of A is the identity matrix), then exp(iAx)=cos(x)+iAsin(x), for any real number x.

I already know why e^(ipi) = -1 but had a hard time following your explanation.  I sympathize with people trying to figure it out.  It is much easier to explain polar co-ordinates in the complex plane.  Even if you just have to state that e^(itheta) = cos(theta) + I sin(theta).  As theta goes from 0 to 2pi, e^(itheta)  describes the unit circle in the complex plane.  The usual rules of exponents (A^(BC) = (A^B) * (A^C)) works!  On of the most useful rules in engineering.  ae^(itheta)*be^(ialpha) = abe^(I(theta+alpha)).  Magnitudes multiply, angles add.  We therefore get I = e^(ipi/2).  I^2 = e^(ipi/2)e^(ipi/2) = e^(ipi) = -1.  Muliplying by I is the same are rotating (adding) by pi/2 angle or 90 degrees.  Pictures make this all so much easier.

I think this is really an explanation for mathematicians more than for lay people; to really follow it, one needs to be comfortable with reframing things in an abstract way, defining functions by functional equations, and choosing things based on naturality. It is a familiar thing to do, also, with many examples in mathematics of great success with this abstract (dare I say relative (a la Grothendieck)) point of view.  And then all you have to do is choose whatever is most natural, which most mathematicians will 'naturally' do, and everything falls out beautifully.  But to many it seems like hand waving, even though it's not; it's definition waving, which I have no problem with at all!

I wanted to share two insights I had while trying to wrestle with the contents of the video and the article.
Firstly, I was wondering whether there existed a function which took in multipliers as inputs and returned adders, and I realised it's just the log! (This may be obvious to some, but it came in as a surprise to me)
Secondly, when we talk about different bases (binary, decimal. hexadecimal etc.) we are using a concept closely related to adders and multipliers: while counting things, we could just keep on sliding the line to infinity, but there's a more practical way to do it. Here's how it works: slide the line by one unit each time up to the point where you get bored (say 9), then instead of sliding one more unit to get to ten you go back to the first unit and bring the point 10 (which you hadn't reached before) to that unit (i.e. you multiply by ten).

This video is HIGHLY misleading!
There is no rotating (on the 2D plane) with pure imaginary numbers. A true rotation REQUIRES real numbers (as well as imaginary numbers). What is described in the video (rotation with pure imaginary numbers) is, how I like to call it, a potential rotation (something which has the potential to rotate).
Imaginary numbers shift the whole 2D plane vertically (up-down), just like the real numbers shift the 2D plane horizontally (left-right). Since a rotation consists of both, vertical and horizontal shifts, the thought of rotating the plane with ONLY real (left-right) or ONLY imaginary (up-down) numbers is nonsense.
What shifting the plane vertically does is create the potential for a rotation, still, without a real part the rotation won't happen.

Following his logic: Adders move the number line, multipliers stretch it. Then applying this to the 2-D plane. A 2-D plane is just two number lines perpendicular to each other. If he's working in the Cartesian plane (x,y) adders would move the plane right/left or up/down and multipliers would stretch the plane. At 4:06 I felt his logic stayed intact. He put in a 1 adder to the y and a 2 adder to the x. But then at 4:12 he adds a rotation property to multiplying. He multiplied the point (2,0) by some numbers in order to get (4,2). I find this weird. Even if you stretched the plane while keeping things evenly spaced (if you stretched in the x direction only the vertical lines move and if you stretch in the y direction only the horizontal lines move) I don't know how you would reach the point (4,2) from (2,0). Only by adding the rotation property is this possible which to me doesn't make intuitive sense with his number line analogy. If instead you think about the point (4,2) not as a point in the Cartesian plane but as a vector magnitude root(20). Root(20) is your multiplier to 1. Although there is a infinite amount of points that are root(20) distance from the origin in a perfect circle. So if root(20) is my multiplier how do I know how much to rotate it to arrive at the point (4,2). I feel in order to satisfy the graphical representation at 4:12 you would need not only the multiplier root(20) but also an angle in order to define it properly. He later provides that this rotation is defined by i. This concept is really what I came here to understand more. Although after re-inventing addition and multiplication and explaining them thoroughly he just adds this rotation in without really explaining it. This makes sense if you know euler's formula although this does not help explain euler's formula itself.

I feel the only way to fully explain the formula is to look at it numerically in the conventional way. e^x, sin(x), and cos(x) are defined by similar infinite series. When the e^(x) includes 'i' which is e^(xi) all the even terms become real and the odd terms become imaginary and amazingly the real terms correspond with the sin(x) infinite series and the imaginary with cos(x) infinite series multiplied by i. It's not really a hard formula to understand, what is amazing about it is the fact that all these unique terms, functions and ratios are related to each other.

Sorry, this is cheating. The crucial part of introducing the "e" is done via series. But... to understand how they work you need calculus which in turn is based on definition of numbers, operations on them and properties of both numbers and operations. You're getting into circular dependencies of your definitions there. And no, saying "it's the most natural way of ..." simply doesn't cut it. It's just saying that the equation you are trying to prove is the most natural! In a way - yes, it is. But you were trying to prove it, right?

In calculus, rotation on the complex plane comes up pretty much by itself, as a consequence of other things you're doing with those numbers. And sure, it's a handy little trick to visualise what's going on for those who use/need visualising (not all people do). But it's no substitute for proper definitions, much less proofs.

Over the years, I've seen a number of similar attempts to redefine how introduction to calculus (and maths in general) in taught to school-level students. I'm not sure if it works or not in school (no idea really, it might help teachers perhaps?) but, as soon as these students are faced with further studies, they are up against the wall: what they've learnt doesn't work. So we have to run remedial crash courses (as part of the intro usually) to help them unlearn the latest fad they were fed at school and start all over again. So, if you like this trick or find it handy to help visualise something - ok, maybe it works for you but remember - this isn't the real thing.
